titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: The first occupation of the day was the reading of the 13. and 14th. Chapters of Exodus containing the narrative of the wonderful emigration of the children of Israel from the Land of Egypt the miracle of their passage through the red sea and the destruction of the Egyptian Hord which pursued them— I then wrote a Letter with my own hand to Francis O. French son of Benjamin B. French Clerk of the House of Representatives a boy of nine years old who through his Father had requested this of me—an operation performed not without difficulty— Mr. Kavasales was the first of the visitors of this morning and he was followed by several hundreds of others, making the New Years visit which for many years past I have been accustomed to receive on this Anniversary— A considerable portion of them consists of Members of Congress among which a small number are of politics opposite to mine and of these there was this day I know not for what reason an unusual number— The assemblage at the Presidents House consisted of immense and almost numberless crowd and among those who came here there were some whose personal conduct towards me had not lead me to expect visits from them— I deem it not necessary however to record their names— The throng of those who came in and went out after a mere salutation continued from about twelve to half past three— At which time I paid my own Annual visit of salutation to Mrs. Madison Her house had also been thronged with visitors most of them the same with those who called upon me. I returned from her House with her nieces—Miss Anna Payne and Miss Mary E E. Cutts— In the evening Mr. E. Carrington Cabill—Member of the House of Representatives from Florida came with Mr. John Goldsborough a Son of the Late Charles Goldsborough the Secretary of the Board of Navy Commissioners— Mr. Cabill’s election is contested and an attempt was made though without success to substitute his competition as the sitting member during the time while the case is before the Committee of Elections— The weather was this day unusually fair for the Season and among my visitors were the Secretaries of War—Marcy—and of the Navy—Bancroft and the Attorney General John Y. Mason—

I called this morning at the Banking House of Corcoran and Riggs, then at the Bank of the Metropolis and next at the Office of J. J. Nourse to deposit, an order from the Speaker of the House for four hundred dollars, which I took in gold and deposited with three hundred dolls in Bills at the Bank of Metropolis upon which I drew a check of 501.25 payable to J. J. Nourse for City Corporation 6. per cent with a brokerage of one quarter of one per cent. Thence I attended at the House A person by the name of Isaac Cole had been here with a subscription paper for the Building of a Methodist Episcopal Church near Dover Mills Baltimore County— I requested him to call here to-morrow— At the House Edwin H. Ewing from Tennessee, elected in the place of Joseph H. Peyton deceased took his seat and was introduced to me by his Colleague—Milton Brown— Francis A. Cunningham—offered a Resolution with a preamble declaring the Negotiation with Great Britain relating to Oregon Territory terminated and that it is the imperative duty of Congress to adopt immediately such measures as will fully protect our Citizens whom now do or may hereafter inhabit that Country and effectually maintain our just title to the whole of the Country of Oregon— McKay Chairman of the Committee of Ways and means objected to the introduction of this Resolution Henly and Wentworth moved a suspension of the Rules to receive this Resolution which was refused by yeas and nays 73. to 89. Soon after a Question arose as to the day appointed for the consideration of the Bill from the Committees on the Territories for extending our Jurisdiction over the whole Territory of Oregon— Garrett Davis moved a suspension of the Rule to introduce a resolution that the Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union should be discharged from the consideration of that Bill and its ten sections be recommitted to seven of the standing Committees of the House— The House refused the suspension of the Rules—a Debate followed concerning the publication of the tenth volume of the Laws. Reports from Committees were called Hugh A. Haralson Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs Reported a Bill to provide for the organiza
tion of two Regiments of Riflery—he moved its referrence to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union and made the special order for next Tuesday— A long Debate followed, at the close of which I took a part in it by a Speech which I fear gave satisfaction to no part of the House when I finished James J. Faran of Ohio moved the suspension of the Rules to offer a Resolution but the House without hearing it read immediately adjourned. W. H. Seward Late Governor of New York came to me at my seat and inquired if I should be at home this evening. I said I should. he promised to call on me and did so with Mr. Robinson who now reports the proceedings of the House for the New York Tribune— I had a long conversation with them in which Mr. Seward declared his full approbation of my speech in the House but some doubt whether it would meet the concurrence of the Whig Party— In coming down the stairs from the House Mr. John W. Houston a Whig member of the State of Delaware had introduced himself to me and told me that he concurred entirely with the sentiments which I had just delivered— This is probably the last great movement of my political Life—it will pass through a fierly ordeal the result of which as concerns myself I leave to the great disposal of events—

Mr. Isaac Cole came again this morning, with his contribution Book for building a Methodist Episcopal Church in Baltimore County to which I subscribed five dollars— I made a deposit of 110. dollars, in the Bank of the Metropolis to escape from overdrawing by a check of five-hundred and one dollars and twenty five cents in favor of J. J. Nourse, to pay for a Certificate of 500. dollars City Corporation 6. per cent which he sent me in the course of the day—including a Charge of one quarter of one per cent for Brokerage— At the House the Debate was immediately resumed on the Question of referrence of the Bill from the Committee of Military Affairs to provide for raising two additional Regiments of Riflemen and for other purposes, to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, and to be made the Special order of the day for next Tuesday the Debate consumed the day and was yet not exhausted— It was commenced this morning by Charles—Jerald
Ingersoll Chairman Committee on Foreign Affairs and was continued by Haralson of Georgia, Darrah of Pennsylvania—Preston King of New York—Robert C Winthrop of Boston—Edward D. Baker of Illinois after an unsuccessful attempt to adjourn and after whose speech Joseph J. McDowell of Ohio took the floor and the adjournment was carried so that as next Monday will be the first weekly day for receiving Petitions—Tuesday will come before the House shall have decided whether they will make it the special order of that day or not. There were two rather curious and whimsical incidents in the Debate of this day—first, of Mr. Charles J. Ingersoll concurred entirely with the views which I had yesterday unfolded in my speech on this Oregon Question and that Mr. Winthrop came out in point-blank opposition to them— Of this more hereafter— Mary and her daughter dined with their friend Mrs. Stockton and spent the evening of yesterday— We amused this evening with various reading

I attended Public Worship this morning at the Hall of the House of Representatives where the two Chaplains were present and Mr. Milburne preached from John 3.16. “For God so loved the world that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish but have everlasting Life”— Mr. McClure in his Comment upon this text made a very explicit exposition of his own Creed for he said that this was perhaps the most solemn and important verse of the whole Bible and further that a very eminent Divine had once said to him that if by any possible calamity every other Book of the Scriptures except the Gospel of St John and if every Chapter of that Book except the 3. should be involved in the same destruction and every verse in that chapter should be swallowed up in the same ruin that verse alone would be of power to supply the place of the whole scriptures of the Old and New Testament— Mr. Milburne expressed no dissent from that saying—and his citation of it and his own observation upon the same text—sufficiently testify the wholesale Calvanism of his Faith
Now the whole of this Chapter carries to my mind a strong suspicion that it was interpolated into the Gospel according to St John some Centuries after the Advent of Jesus Christ. The verse is a part of the conversation between Jesus at a very early period of his ministry and Nicodemus a Ruler of the Jews, who came to him by night and told him that they knew he was a Teacher come from God, because he had performed miracles such as no man could do except God were with him— Jesus thereupon announces to him the Doctrine of regeneration and solemnly declares that “except a man be born again, he cannot see the Kingdom of God” Nicodemus amazed at this declaration enquires how this can possibly be. Whereupon Jesus replies—but foreshadowing the event of his own death and adds this verse representing the Love of God to the world as so great, as to have given his only begotten Son as a sacrifice to secure everlasting life to all who should believe in him— This declaration implied but did not expressly assert that he was himself the only begotten Son of God but not only did it make not the most distant intimation that He was himself a person of the Godhead but directly excluded that idea by assuming that He was the Son of God sent by him on a mission to the World of mankind— If then, this single verse contains the whole Doctrine of the Christian Faith it certainly gives no countenance to the Doctrine of the Trinity or of the Divinity of Christ himself but is of itself an irrefragable testimony against those articles of a Creed— If he was the Son of God—he could not be God, if he was sent by God—he could not have sent himself and if this text is the all important Text of the whole scriptures it is fatal to the belief of a God in three Persons— In the afternoon at St Johns Church the Revd. Mr. Pyne read the evening service for the 2d. Sunday after Christmas and the Epiphany and preached from Ecclesiastes 8. part of 5. verse “A wise man’s heart discerneth both time and judgment” a sensible Discourse on the employment of time— We had no visitors this evening which my Grandaughter spent at Mrs. Madisons—

The House were in Session this morning when I reached my seat and Garrett Davis of Kentucky a Member of the Committee of Foreign Affairs was presenting a Report from the Minority of that Committee signed by himself Truman Smith of Connect.
and Caleb B. Smith of Indiana, against the report which had just before been made by Charles J. Ingersol Chairman of that Committee of the following Joint resolution— Resolved (the Senate concurring) that the President of the United States forthwith cause the notice to be given to the Government of Great Britain that the Convention between the United States and Great Britain concerning the Territory of Oregon of the 6th. of August 1827. Signed at London shall be annulled and abrogated twelve months after the expiration of the said term of notice conformably to the second Article of the said Convention of the 6th. of August 1827— And with the report Ingersol had moved by Instruction of the Committee that the resolution should be referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union and made the special Order of the day for the first Monday in February next— The report of the Minority concluded with the following resolution— Resolved that the Question whether a notice to terminate the Convention between the United States of America and Great Britain of October 1818—and continued in force by the Convention of August 1827. ought to be given is not a matter for the decision of Congress, and upon it this House at the present refrains from the expression of any Opinion— The Question debated was whether the resolution reported by the Committee should be made the Special Order of the day for the first Monday in February— Joshua R Giddings of Ohio after enquiring of the Speaker whether upon that Question the merits of the resolution reported might be discussed and being answered that to some extent they might made an hours Speech in favor of the resolution admitting that differing in Opinion from one in believing that it would be followed by War and holding War in utter abhorrence he still preferred it with all its horrors to the State into which we were now reduced by the Annexation of Texas to this Union the Subversion by that event of the balance of Power held until that time by the Free States of this Union the Government of which was now transferred to an Oligarchy of Slave holders to restore that balance the Occupation of the whole Territory of Oregon by the United States was indispensably necessary he should therefore go for it and hoped for the preliminary notice to be given to Great Britain of the termination of the Convention of 1827. as required by that Convention itself— He was followed by MacDowell of the same State who disclaiming all his arguments concurred in his intention of voting for the resolution— Robert D. Rhett of South Carolina a member of the Committee of Foreign affairs who had refused to vote either for the resolution of the Committee or for the Minority report against it, now in an hours speech opposed the giving of the notice with all his ability and all his fire— In the course of his Speech he made a deadset against me by saying that the Gentleman from Massachusetts across the way had shown himself a Hero by voting against the last War with England but now was rabid for War with her—for though he said he was for Peace all knew
that the tendency and effect of his policy was War— Whereupon I rose and enquired whether the Gentleman in what he had just said about a gentleman from Massachusetts voting against the last War had alluded to me— He answered that he had— I replied the Gentleman is mistaken— He rejoined that at all events I did not support it— I said that the last War had commenced in 1812 that three years before that time I had been appointed in consequence of the support of the measures of Mr. Jeffersons Administration against Great Britain, Minister of the United States in Russia, that these were facts not known to the Gentleman from South Carolina and after expressing some surprise that he should have ventured to make such a charge as he had done against me I was willing to impute it to ignorance and not to malignity— Rhett clawed off as well as he could by acknowledging his ignorance and by insinuating that I was not of importance enough for him to have known what my conduct had heretofore been—by expressing his horror upon the disastrous conjunction on this occasion between me and Giddings and upon my inveterate unmitigated hostility to the South whence his Constituents expected whenever they saw my vote on one side of a question to see his on the other— When he concluded Simms of Missouri made a speech in favor of giving the notice and the House adjourned— Coll. Totten Chief Engineer and Alexr D. Bache Superintendant of the Coast Survey called here this evening— Coll. Totten put into my hands a printed extract from his report to the Secretary of War arguing the necessity of raising a Company of Sappers, Miners, and Pontoniers—upon which he dwelt also with great earnestness in conversation with me—

6. III.45— V.— I called this morning at the Office of the Chief Engineer with a Letter from the Revd. John P. Robinson to Mrs. Adams renewing his solicitation in behalf of his Son Milnor Robinson for a warrant of Cadet at the Military Academy of West Point— I found that his name had been entered on the books of the Department early in 1844. but without his Christian name and with an erroneous note that he was then 18 years old— His father now writes that he will be sixteen next July— I requested and was promised the correction of the Note and the insertion of his Christian name— I next called at the Bank of Washington and received an Order for ninety seven dollars and fifty cents a dividend due on the first of this month on the City Corporation six per cents standing in my name— At the House Haraldson of Georgia Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs moved that the Bill reported by him on the second instt to raise two additional regiments of Riflemen and for other purposes should be referred to the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union and ordered to be Printed—which was done— McConnell of Alabama moved four ridiculous resolutions proposing that Ireland should have the privilege of being Annexed to the Union which was received and treated as a choice speciman of
buffoonery— The debate was resumed upon Ingersoll’s motion to refer the report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs the notice to be given to Great Britain of the termination in twelve months of the Convention of the 6th. August 1827. concerning Oregon to be referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union and made the special order of the day for the first of February— Hilliard of Alabama was entitled to the floor. Preston King of New York made a personal explanation of what he had said intimating that after the conclusion of the Ashburton Treaty there was a secret understanding between Lord Ashburton Mr. Webster and Mr. Calhoun, that if Great Britain would not interfere against the Annexation of Texas to the United States the Territory of Oregon might be divided— A sparring altercation followed between Preston King and Rhett of South Carolina who took offence at this insinuation against Mr. Calhoun— Hilliard of Alabama then proceeded with a very eloquent hour Speech in favor of giving the notice but concluding by proposing an Amendment to the reported resolution authorising the President to give the notice whenever he should think it required by the interest and honour of the United States— At the motion of Thompson of Mississippi and after some discussion the question was divided and taken first upon the reference to the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union which required only a Majority and was adopted without opposition and next upon making it the special Order for the 1st. of February which required a vote of two thirds and was lost by Yeas and Nays 102. to 89. a majority but not two thirds— Bowlin of Missouri then moved to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union which was agreed to and he made a Speech in favor of giving the notice—not much attended to by the House— Yancy of Alabama took the floor the Committee Arose and the House adjourned—

I deposited in the Bank of Metropolis the order for ninety seven dollars fifty cents received yesterday at the Bank of Washington.— I found the House in Session and in a very few minutes Rhett of South Carolina renewed his attack upon me by reading the report in the Union newspaper of his charges against me made on Monday last and now repeating the charge that I had been opposed to the War and produced his Vouchers part of my conversation with the Chancellor Count Romanzoff when he first proposed the Emperor Alexander’s Mediation for Peace between the United States and Great Britain and an Extract of my Letter to Levitt Harris written at Ghent in 1814. I repelled this renewed attack by relating circumstances under which I had made the remarks to Count Romanzoff and under which I had written the letter to Levitt Harris showing that the charge of my having been opposed to the War inferred by Mr. Rhett from these incidents was utterly unfounded and that his charge of hostility to the South on my part was equally false for proof of which I referred specially to my successful exertions in obtaining indemnity for the Slaves taken
and carried away by the British during the last War— I exposed the prevarication of his conduct towards me in these repeated wanton and unprovoked assaults on me and concluded by saying, I wished to have nothing further to do with him— On my saying that I apprehended no War because I believed that the present Administration would finally back out from their own ground Yancy of Alabama called me to order for reflecting upon the Administration—and the Speaker as usual set me down for irrelevancy— Yancy objected to my proceeding but after special permission from the House a Motion was made immediately that I should have leave to proceed to which a unanimous Answer of Aye with a single exception of Yancy himself— Rhett closed with a wandering silly, general diatribe in which he admitted my services in obtaining indemnity for the Slaves lost in the last War and said that the South had made me President of the United States— To which I made no reply— Holmes of South Carolina moved a resolution authorising the President of the United States to assign a Lot of Ground, upon which the Washington National Monument Society may erect their proposed Monument to the Memory of George Washington—which was read three times and passed without opposition— Hamlin of Maine from the Committee of Elections presented a report declaring Cabell the sitting Member from Florida not entitled to his Seat and his Competitor W. Brockenbrough duly Elected— Erastus D. Culver of New York presented a Minority Counter report— The Oregon Question was resumed, Yancy of Alabama made an hours speech against giving the notice and Caleb B. Smith a Whig Member from Indiana, made another upon the same side— The Committee then rose and at a quarter past three the House adjourned— We had evening visits from Mr. John Connell and from J. M. Shively an Inhabitant of Astoria a settlement at the mouth of the Columbia River— He had given me a small printed pamphlet entitled route and distances to Oregon and California—but I had forgotten it and mislaid his pamphlet upon which he now gave me another copy— He had also much conversation upon the subject— Mr. Connell had many reminiscenses of the last War with Great Britain and of the Negotiation of Peace at Ghent—

Morning visit from Mr. Robert Owen still full of his magnificent projects for a total abolition of the whole world of mankind and the universal reformation of all human Society.— Just as I was going to the House Mr. Benjamin Thompson of Charlestown, Member of the House from the 4th Congressional District of Massachusetts with his wife paid us a visit— I was consequently delayed and found the House in Session— Andrew Johnson of Tennessee was moving an Amendment to a Bill reported by his Colleague William M Cocke from the Committee of Invalid Pensions in favour of Joseph M. Rhea to commence the first of January 1846 Johnson’s
Amendment was to make the Pension commence at the date of the application which was in 1835. He was urging in a snarling tone the lavish manner in which Congress was always ready to make extravagant appropriations for the District of Columbia contrasted with the stinginess with which they were always ready to refuse or contract Pensions to the poor war worn Soldier— Giddings called him to order, and the Speaker requiring him to state his point of order said it was that the appropriations for the District of Columbia had nothing to do with the time when the Pension to Joseph M. Rhea should commence— The Speaker decided that Johnson was in Order whereupon Johnson thanked him for his decision and insultingly said he thanked the gentleman from Ohio also Giddings, for not making a Speech on Abolition and Slavery in stating his point of Order— Giddings called him to order again and now the Speaker said that Johnson was not strictly in order and requested him to confine his remark to the subject before the House— Giddings called for a positive decision whether Johnson was or was not in Order, the Speaker said that he was not, and again requested Johnson to proceed in Order— Giddings denied the right of the Speaker to authorize Johnson to proceed without a formal vote of the House— And this is uniformly the practise of the Speaker when he decides that any other than a Slavemonger is out of order— He made no reply to Giddings but a Motion was made and carried without opposition that Johnson should have leave to proceed— He soon finished and Cocke assigned the reasons of the Committee for fixing the commencement of the Pension to the first of January 1846. The Bill was referred to the Committee of the Whole— McKay Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means reported the five Annual Appropriation Bills which were referred to the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union. After sundry other reports from Committees, at the expiration of the morning hour the House went into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, Tibbatts in the Chair, Petit of Indiana moved that the Committee should rise that the House might adjourn because it was the 8th. of January but the Speaker said that the member from Georgia Cobb had the floor upon the Oregon question and that he could not receive Petits motion for the Committee to rise— Mr. Cobb accordingly made an hours Speech in favor of giving the notice in the form reported by the Committee of Foreign Affairs assigning reasons for his objections to the Amendment proposed by Mr. Hilliard—which he thought would be to shrink from the responsibility which ought to be assumed by Congress in casting it off in the spiritless manner upon the President— He was followed by McClernamnd of Illinois in favor also of giving the notice whose Argument was chiefly directed against the report of the minority of the Committee of Foreign Affairs which questions the Power of Congress to decide upon this subject and considers it the exclusive duty and power of the Executive Department— The next successful Candidate for the floor was William F Giles of Maryland who moved that the Committee should rise which was carried—and he
We had evening visits from our Neighbour Mr. Parris with the Reverend Mr. Smith of Boston, who is engaged for some time to preach at the 2d. Presbyterian Church to supply the place vacated by Mr. Knox—and also from Mr. Shively the self authorised settler and Claimant of the property of Astoria— He showed me several maps of the North Western Coast and a plan of the Town of Astoria as surveyed by himself—he said also that the Map in Greenhow’s history was very incorrect laying down Rivers where there were none and omitting others where they were—he added repeatedly that the Map of Captain Wilkes in his account of the Exploring Expedition was the only correct representation of that region of Country—

I attended this morning the second Meeting of the Select Committee on the Smithsonian bequest— Consisting of Robert Dale Owen of Indiana, myself, Timothy Jenkins of New York, George P. Marsh of Vermont, Alexander D. Simms of South Carolina, Jefferson Davis of Mississippi, and David Wilmot of Pennsylvania—seven. Of whom Simms and Wilmot were this day absent— The first meeting of this Committee was held last Saturday, Owen the Chairman had notified me the day before of the Meeting but I forgot the notification and did not attend— The Bill introduced by Mr. Owen had then been taken up and partially discussed but was not printed—it was again taken up this morning, read through, and further discussed, but not seperately considered by Sections—it was the same Bill with some immaterial alterations which passed the Senate at the last Session and the passage of which without discussion or debate I with great difficulty prevented on the last night of the Session— I now enquired if in framing of this Bill any notice whatever had been taken of the Bill reported by the Committee of the House in June 1844 at the first Session of the last Congress— It appeared that there was not and Mr. Owen said that it had been his impression, and he believed that of the Members of the House generally that the purport of that Bill was to apply the whole Smithsonian Fund to the Erection of an Astronomical Observatory though he had since read the Bill and found that it proposed only the appropriation of seven years interest of the Fund to the latter object— It was not however that Bill but the one reported at the preceding Congress which Mr. Owen had read for the Bill of June 1844 proposed to apply ten years of the Interest of the Smithsonian Fund to the Establishment and perpetual support of an observatory— I now said that I had given up all idea of Appropriating any part of this fund to an Astronomical Observatory in as much as Congress had already established one by Law under the austensible provision of a Depot for Maps and Charts, the Observatory was built it had one of the finest Frauenhofer Refractors in the World and skilful Naval Officers for
Observers— The application of the Smithsonian fund must be devoted to other objects I should propose therefore that at the next meeting of the Committee a Bill introduced by the Chairman and referred to this Committee should be taken up and considered by Sections, which was agreed to—but I observed that the Bill provided an Appropriation from the public Treasury without including any provision for the recovery of the Fund itself, which had been invested in Bonds of the States of Arkansas, Michigan, Illinois, and Ohio upon which excepting a small Portion in Ohio neither Principal nor Interest has been paid— Mr. Owen then recurred to the Bill reported by the Committee of the House in June 1844 and moved to insert into the present Bill the provision entailed in that Bill for the recovery of the money vested in the Stocks of those four States—which was done and the Committee adjourned to meet next Friday— In the House Wentworth of Illinois moved to suspend the rules to receive Bills of which notice had been given and notices of Bills not occasioning Debate— Rejected— Truman Smith offered a Resolution to arrest the scramble for the floor by requiring the members who propose to speak on the Resolution for giving notice of the termination of the Convention of August 1827. should hand their names to the Chairman of the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union and should have the right to the floor each in his turn—but the House refused to Suspend the rules to receive this resolution— William G. Brown of Virginia moved a Resolution of Enquiry of the Committee of Post Offices and Post Roads about a letter from the Post Master General published in the Union Newspaper of the 6th. instt complaining of the abuse of the Franking privilege by members of Congress—but the suspension of the rules was refused by Yeas and Nays 101. to 65—not two thirds— McKay Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means introduced two Annual Pension appropriation Bills— Sundry other Bills and Notices were received—the Resolution of Notice was then resumed and Howel Cobb of Georgia and Lewis C. Levin of Pennsylvania delivered two successive hour Speeches in favor of giving the notice, and R. M. T. Hunter of Virginia moved the Committee to rise which was done and the House adjourned— Evening visit from Mr. Richard D. Cutts— My Granddaughter M. Louisa is afflicted with a sore throat, my wife has a horse cough and I myself am all but disabled for the performance of my public duties—

Mr. John Gray was again here this morning, and had some conversation with me respecting the relative powers of Congress and of the Judicial Tribunals—upon which he had left a Dissertation with me and also upon the Bill for the relief of the Legal Representatives of James Bell. I had not entirely read through his dissertation but so far as I understood it I told him I
agreed in principles maintained in it—with regard to the Bill it has not yet passed the Senate and I can do nothing respecting it until it shall come into the House— Mrs. Beck was also again here but there has been no opportunity yet for the presentation of her Petition. I again assured her that there could be no occasion nor any use to her to remain here—if she had any motive for immediately returning home that I would present her Petition at the first possible opportunity it would be referred to one of the Committees on Pensions and several months would pass before any decisive action of the House upon it— She appeared however resolved to remain here having received assurances from Mr. and Mrs. Obadiah Brown at whose house she lodges that she may remain there without charge as long as she desires— The Revd. Mr. Dewey herebefore a Secretary of the American Bible Society called being now here with the purpose of preaching upon the purposes of the Peace Society. He had called on me once before mentioned that it had been his intention to apply for the use of the Hall of the House of Representatives to deliver a Discourse in behalf of Peace upon some week day but that he had been informed that in the present state of Public Affairs it might be considered as assuming a political and Party aspect and had therefore concluded not to make the request— I approved of that determination but told him that it was usual for the Chaplains of the House to invite a brother Clergyman happening to be here during the Session of Congress to preach for them on Sunday morning. That I had no doubt either of the Chaplains would willingly give him the opportunity of delivering a Discourse in favor of peace and leave to his discretion his manner of treating the subject. Mr. John Otis of Barnstable was also here and came to take leave being about to return home—he made some enquiry concerning a Petition presented for him in the year 1840—of the present state of which I was not able to inform but promised to make enquiry and let him know. He spoke with great satisfaction of the management by Mr. Lewis Johnson, of the Claims of the Heirs of his brother William Otis— At the House Charles Hudson member from the fifth Congressional District Massachusetts complained of a Breach of privilege in an article in the Union Newspaper, the Editors of which are the Printers of the House and in which he was charged with falsehood by charging
unecessary delay in the delivery to the Members of the House of the Pub. Doc printed by its order Mr. Hudson made a statement proving that his charge had been perfectly well founded with regard to the delay and after justifying himself said that he had no motion to make but left the House to act in the matter as they should think proper— In making this statement Mr. Hudson was repeatedly, rudely and insultingly interrupted by Felix. G. McConnell of Alabama by calls to order which the speaker did not sustain and of which Hudson himself took no notice. When he closed Garrett Davis of Kentucky offered the following Resolution “Whereas John P. Heiss a person in the employment of this House having in a newspaper charged Charles Hudson a Member of this House with falsehood in Debate therefore resolved that the said John P. Heiss be dismissed from the employment of the House as one of its Printers.” This immediately started an angry and disorderly Debate in which McConnell insulted Garrett Davis several times till Davis said—“I take no notice of a drunken blaguard” which produced quite a sensation—but some of McConnell’s friends gathered round him and prevailed upon him to leave the House to which he did not this day return— A long Debate followed upon Garrett Davis Resolution which was finally laid on the Table on a motion of Thomas H. Bayly of Virginia at the close of a long Speech The vote to lay on the Table by yeas and nays was 100. to 85. I voted in the affirmative alone of all the Members in opposition to the Administration in the House— After the adjournment Mr. Giddings asked me why I had so voted I said that if the Resolution had passed not been laid on Table the Printer Heiss must first have been heard in his defence that whether his defence was good or bad and it was clear it could not be good the majority of the House would certainly have acquitted him and he would have come off with flying colours giving the appearance before the Public that he was in the right and Mr. Hudson in the wrong— Mr. Giddings said he supposed this was my motive. This flurry being over the Oregon Notice Question was resumed— R. M. T. Hunter of Va made a very animated speech against giving the notice and Andrew Kennedy of Indiana one still more vehement in its favor
After which the House adjourned—This evening a man by name Charles Saxton came with a prospectus for a publication concerning the Oregon Territory for which he desired me to subscribe— He comes himself from that region of Country and is about to publish this work in concert with a man by name of Scovil. Not knowing what the character of the work will be I prefered waiting for its publication rather than subscribe for it in advance—

I attended Public Worship this morning at the Hall of the House Representatives—which was not very fully attended Revd. Mr. Dewey who had called on me yesterday made the prayer and gave out for singing the 100th. Psalm— Mr. Dewey did not Preach for peace, but Mr. Tustan the Chaplain of Senate, did. His text was from Luke 19.41. “And when he was come near he beheld the City and wept over it.” 42. “Saying if though hadst known even thou at least in this thy Day the things which belong unto thy peace! But now they are hid from thine eyes” This text is surely a strong recommendation for peace but I had heard in substance the same Discourse from Mr. Tustan once before and now he carefully avoided all political allusion in his Discourse. The peace upon which he commented was the individual peace of mind of his Christian Auditors— In the afternoon at St John’s Church, Mr. Pyne whom I found chatechizing the children before commencing the Service read the evening prayers for the first Sunday after Epiphany, and preached from Philippians 2.5. “Let this mind be in you which was also in Christ Jesus.” This is the verse immediately before that of more than doubtful authenticity which is the great reliance of the Believers in the Divinity of Jesus Christ and the Trinitarians—its words being “Who being in the form of God thought it not robbery to be equal with God” Mr. Pyne however did not venture to approach this controversy— The tenor of his Discourse was merely an exhortation to his Auditory to immitate the example of Jesus Christ in his humility, his brotherly kindness, his charity and universal benevolence— Mr. Charles Nichols Consul of the United States at Amsterdam now in this Country by leave of absence was here this evening— He is now about to return to his Post and leaves the City to-morrow
morning— He was here in 1841. and 42. soliciting the appointment which he holds and which he finally obtained from Mr. Tyler— He said there was an intention on the part of the present Secretary of State to bring before Congress a plan for reorganizing the Consular system to which he requested my particular attention. A reorganization of that system has been proposed by successive Secretaries of State almost from the first organization of the Government of the United States but never has been successful and probably never will be— Mr. Nichols complained of great abuses of which there is no doubt. All commerce is subject to great abuses and seeking for a remedy seldom if ever ends unless by the substitution of other and greater abuses

Before the meeting of the House Mr. Thomas Sinn was here— At the House Robert Smith Illinois moved for permission to present certain papers of importance connected with the defences of the Country and objection was made to their reception and the Speaker commenced the call of the States for Petitions beginning with State of Maine only two or three were presented before he came to Massachusetts and only two or three from the members from that Commonwealth till it came to my turn when I presented 121. Remonstrances, Memorials and Petitions from every State North and West of South Carolina— Of these all but six or eight were Remonstrances against the admission of Texas as a slave state into the Union— A work already consummated and they were all tacitly laid on Table They were however received and I requested the Clerk that they might be entered on Journal of the House as I had presented that is giving the name of the first Petitioner or Signer to the Remonstrance the number of signers to the paper the state to which they belong and the County or Town when they were designated—which the Clerk promised should be done This mode of entry being necessary to show that every Petition was actually presented to the House— The mode of entry heretofore having been simply that sundry Petitions numerously signed were presented. The Clerk promised that the entry should be made— I was an hour and a quarter in performing this service and after a single memorial presented by
Arnold of Rhode Island, McDowell of Ohio moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and John W. Tibbatts took the Chair— Robert Toombs of Georgia made a powerful hour speech in support of the Resolution to give the notice with the amendment proposed by Hilliard— Joseph R. Ingersoll proposed an amendment to that of Mr. Hilliard that the President be authorized to open a negotiation with Great Britain for terminating the Convention of 1818. by mutual consent. Hannibal Hamlin of Maine followed with an hour speech in favor of giving the notice— Douglass of Illinois Chairman of the Committee on the Territories observing that tomorrow had been fixed by special order for the consideration of the Bill reported by him to protect the American settlers in Oregon moved to discharge the Committee of the whole on state of the Union from the consideration of that Bill and that it be recommitted to the Committee on the territories which was agreed to without opposition. William W. Wick of Indiana moved that the use of the Hall should be allowed for the Colinezation Society on the 20th. instt. which was refused by the House— Lucien B. Chase of Tennessee took the floor on the notice Question— Committee rose and the House adjourned. Evening visit from Capt Casey—and I spent the evening with a very large Company of men at Mr. Seatons— Mr. Toombs of Georgia offered me his hand which I took very cordially and thanked him for his speech. I had some conversation with Mr. William C. Johnson upon his Report of a Select Committee in February 1843. of which I was a member and which asserted the right of the United States to Latitude 54:40. on the Northwest Coast. The Report which was unanimously signed by the members of the Committee and which he has recently published— There was a magnificent supper from which I retired soon after 10—with loss of my hat and a narrow escape of losing my coat. Mr. Seaton lent me a white Summer hat to come home with—
I received this morning a Letter from Lieut. Joseph. H. Adams, dated at Masatlan 30. November on board U.S. Ship Levant enclosing two Letters for his sister Elizabeth. C. Adams. and

requesting me to obtain for him if possible a permission to return home in consequence of the death of his mother of which he had just received the information. He being under an apprehension that the Levant would be detained a year longer in the Pacific I went immediately to the Navy Department but Mr. Bancroft the Secretary was attending Cabinet Council at the President’s— I read the Lieutenant’s Letter to the Chief Clerk who said that the Levant would probably return to the United States in the Spring but that he would report to the Secretary my request in behalf of Lieut. Joseph. H. Adams and inform me of the result. On my way to the Capitol I stopt and purchased a hat a very shabby one having been sent me from Mr. Seatons this morning— At the House the Committees were called for Reports Edward W. Hubard of Virginia moved a Resolution concerning the Publication of the Account of Captain Wilkes exploring expedition— Charles J. Ingersoll offered a Resolution requiring of the Secretary of the Treasury to Report a plan for a Constitutional Treasury which was laid over for consideration— The States were then in motion of Vinton of Ohio—called for Resolutions a multitude of which were presented among which one by Henry Grider of Kentucky requiring the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions to Report a Bill to extend the right of drawing Revolutionary Pensions to widows married after 1794. and before 1800. which occasioning some Debate was laid over for further consideration John W. Tibbatts introduced a Bill making appropriation for the improvement of the Harbour of Cincinnati and the river Ohio. Stephen Adams of Mississippi objected to its being read a second time and the Question of the rejection of the Bill failed by yeas and nays 57. to 108. It was referred to the Committee on Commerce— George W. Jones of Tennessee offered a Resolution that the Clerk of the House should distribute among the members of the present Congress the Copies of Captain Fremont’s Report which the House had ordered to be distributed among the members of the last Congress who are not the members
of the present Congress— Jones moved the Previous Question upon his Resolution— Washington Hunt of New-York moved to lay it on the Table this was refused by yeas and nays 63 to 105. and Jones plundering resolution was passed without a disision— The same George. W. Jones, moved that the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to enquire into the propriety of repealing the fourth Section of the general appropriation Bill of the last session of Congress, which was adopted and Andrew Johnson of Tennessee moved sundry Resolutions to establish the principle of rotation in the subordinate Executive Offices limiting them to the longest term of eight years— Edward D. Baker of Illinois offered a Resolution that in the opinion of the House the President of United States cannot with a just regard to the honor of the Nation offer to surrender whether by Treaty or otherwise to any foreign Power any Territory to which in his opinion we have a clear and unquestionable title— The House adjourned quarter past three o’clock. We had a Company of eight gentlemen to dinner and evening visits from Mr. Healy and Mr Dubourjal recently arrived from Boston—

Lieut Jos. H. Adams in his Letter yesterday received dated U.S. Ship Levant Masatlan 30. November 1845. states that he had recd. from Captain Marston who had seen it in the Newspapers the account of the death of his Mother which occurred on the 3d. last September— He requests me to ask my Son to pay the interest of his money to his Sister Elizabeth— At the House yesterday Samuel F Vinton of Ohio offered a Joint Resolution for an Amendment to the Constitution of the U.S. by which in and after the year 1860. the Election of President of the U.S. shall be elected by the People complicated with an Election by lot. This proposition was referred to the Committee of the whole on state of the Union. This Day the House went immediately into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union—upon the Resolution of Notice to terminate the Oregon Convention of 6 August 1827. F. P. Stanton of Tenn Samuel— Gordon of New-York Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio— John
Wentworth Illinois—and John S. Chipman of Michigan made successive Speeches all in favor of giving the notice. After which the Committee rose and Hannibal Hamlin of Maine from the Committee of Elections gave notice that he should next Friday move to take up the Report of the Committee of Elections against Edward. C. Cabbill the sitting member from Florida and in favor of William H. Brokinbro claiming the seat— Moses Norris of New Hampshire moved to reconsider the vote of yesterday adopting the Resolution offered by Charles. J. Ingersoll calling on the Secretary of the Treasury to Report to the House a new plan for a Constitutional Treasury but it seems the Resolution was not adopted but was laid over for Debate—the House adjourned at 1/2 past three— Mr Strong Member of the House from the State of New York was here a few minutes this evening with two of his friends whom he introduced but whose names have escaped my recollection. With my Wife, our daughter, Mary, and her daughter Louisa were present at the marriage of Miss Mary E. S. Jesup daughter of our neighbour General Thomas Jesup to Mr. James L. Blair passed midshipman in the Navy of the United States and Son of Francis P. Blair Senior Editor of the Globe newspaper. They were married according to the Episcopal Forms by the Revd. Smith Pyne rector of St Johns Church in this City— The Company present consisted of aboutand formed with respect to Political feelings as strange an assemblage as could have been assembled in this City

At the House John A. McClernand report from the Committee on Public Lands an amendetory Bill to reduce and graduate the price of Public Lands to actual settlers and cultivators— The original was introduced by him on the 19th. Dec 1845 and its object is to diminish the price of Public Lands a policy pursued by all the members from the Western States to make what is called political capital by continually diminishing the price for lands until it shall ultimately become equivalent to giving them away
The system of land sales when first established fixed their price at 2. dolls an Acre and Millions of Acres were sold at that price which ought never to have been reduced by dint of perpetual importunity the price had already been reduced to one dollar and a quarter an Acre and by the same process the whole system will be ultimately dissoved till the lands will be given away. This Bill proposes gradually to reduce the price to one dollar to 75 cents to fifty and twenty five cents. It was referred to Committee on the whole for state of the Union. Charles J. Ingersoll Chairman Committee Foreign Affairs reported a Bill to carry into effect a Convention with Peru concluded at Lima March 17. 1841. it was referred to the same Committee Other reports were received from several Committees till the House went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union. Tibbatts in the Chair on the Oregon Notice Resolution from the Committee on Foreign Affairs— William M. Cock of Tennessee, Henry Bedinger of Virginia made hour Speeches against giving the notice, and Isaac E. Morse of Louisiana and James C Dobbin of North Carolina, hour Speeches in the affirmative John A. Rockwell of Connecticut took the floor and the House adjourned at 1/2 past three— Isaac Hull Adams arrived here last evening, sick, and is staying at the House of his friend Archibald Campbell Junior I went there early this evening and saw him in bed confined with a severe attack of Erysipelas his face much swollen and inflamed and having been very unwell while on his way from Boston— I afterwards attended an evening Party of gentlemen Benjamin Ogle Tayloe’s. I met there many others of a mixed company Mr W. H. Seward of New York who introduced to me W. W. Campbell one of the Representatives from the City of New-York They had called on their way at our House where Mrs. Campbell had also visited this morning— Mr. Buchanan Secretary of State said he wished to have some conversation with me and would call on me some morning for that purpose in relation to the state of our affairs with Great Britain— I told him I should be glad to see him any morning before I go to the Capitol—

16— VI.30. At ten o’clock I attended the select Committee on the Smithsonian Bequest. Members present were Owen Chairman, Adams, Jenkins, Marsh, Simms and Davis absent Wilmot of Pennsylvania. The Bill introduced by Mr. Owen was taken up by sections. The first section containing the appropriation from the Treasury equal to the principal of the Bequest and of the interest from the time when it was received at the amnt at 6. per cent a year was passed over without comment. The second Section of the Bill proposes to institute a Board of Directors, without formal Incorporation but invested with corporate powers Mr. Simms of South Carolina stated that this would be to him a vital objection— I moved that the Board of Directors be constituted formally a Corporation with corporate Powers, Succession and liabilities as has been done in all the Bills heretofore reported to the House by former Committees and that the Section in the Bill reported to the last Congress in June 1844. should be substituted as an Amendment to Mr. Owen’s Bill. I moved also that minutes should be kept of the proceedings of the Committee and the yeas and nays recorded upon every Question taken by the Committee when desired by any one of its members— This was agreed to and the Question of the substitution of the formal Corporation for the informal one in Mr. Owens Bill was carried by four votes to one— Davis of Missouri the Chairman not voting and Simms of South Carolina voting for the substitution but with a declared intention to vote also against the substitute or a Corporation in any form. It was then agreed to pass over this Section for the present. The Question was discussed whether the number of Members of Congress to constitute the portion of the Corporation should be two or three in each House and also by what tenure and for what term of time they should hold their Offices. There was also some discussion whether any members of Congress should form a part of the Board of Directors. No conclusion was taken upon this Section and the Committee at noon adjourned till next Friday— At the House Hannibal Hamlin had some days ago given notice that he should this day move the House to take into consideration the Report of the Committee of elections on the contested election from Florida. he said now that he did not then know that Mr. Cabill the sitting Member was absent from the City, he had been informed that he was expected to return this day. He should therefore not move to take up the case this day, but if he should return he would move to take it up to-morrow and whether he should return or not he proposed to call up the report next Monday. McKay Chairman Committee Ways and Means reported the Annual appropriation Bill for the support of the Military Academy at West Point. Haralson Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs reported without Amendment the Bill from the Senate for raising regiment
of Mounted Riflemen and for establishing Military stations on the route to Oregon moved its referrence to Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and said that when it should be taken up he was instructed to move to amend it by substituting the Bill of the House already referred to that Committee for raising two additional regiments of Riflemen. Charles J. Ingersoll reported from Committee on Foreign Affairs a Bill to regulate the allowance for extra services by Secretaries of Legation and Consuls referred to Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Sundry other Bills were reported and two Bills were introduced by Joseph R. Ingersoll, one to abolish certain Custom House oaths and the other to abolish Public executions in Capital cases. Both referred to Committee of the whole on state of the Union— The House went into that Committee Tibbatts in the Chair and the Oregon Notice Resolution when Mr. Rockwell of Connecticut made a very handsome hour-speech concluding with an Amendment, to authorize the President to give the notice at his discretion but not till after the close of the present Session of Congress. The same proposition which has already been made in the Senate by J. J. Crittenden of Ky. James Pollock of Pennsylvania, and Charles Goodyear of New York followed with hour speeches in favour of giving the notice, and John S. Pendleton of Virginia took the floor to speak to-morrow against it, but the Committee rose and the House adjourned— In the evening Mrs. John Adams and her daughter went to the Wedding Ball at General Jesup’s, from whence they did not return till one o’clock to-morrow morning—

William Taylor of Lexington Virginia a Member of the House of Representatives died somewhat suddenly at four o’clock this morning at his lodgings in this City. He was so little noted that I did not know there was a member of that name in the House nor had I heard that he was even indisposed— I heard of his death however before breakfast this morning and went to the House expecting according to the usual custom it would be announced, and that the House as usual after the obituary Resolutions would immediately adjourn—but it was not so— At the House, Mr. Cabill as yet representing the state of Florida presented several Memorials and Resolutions of the Legislature of that State, and Haralson and Lumpkin presented Resolutions from
the Legislature of Georgia. On motion of Jacob Thompson of Mississippi Resolution was passed calling on Secretary of War for Documents and papers relating to Lands among the Cherokee Indians. Felix G. McConnell of Alabama moved a Resolution instructing the Committee of Ways and Means to inquire into the expediency of reducing or repealing the import duty on two of the prime necessaries of Life Salt and Iron—laid over for Debate— On motion of Charles J. Ingersoll the House went into Committee of the whole on State of the Union and took up not the Oregon Notice Resolution but a Bill to carry into effect the Convention between the United States and the Republic of Peru concluded at Lima March 17. 1841. Ruben Chapman of Alabama in the Chair A Debate of two hours ensued on certain provisions in the Bill which proposed to grant two thousand dolls as compensation to the Attorney General of the United States, for acting as a Commissioner for settling the Claims of persons for whose indemnity, the appropriations in the Bill were proposed. There was objection to making any allowance to the Attorney General for this service the argument being that his Salary as Attorney General was full compensation for all services that could be required from him another objection was to the amount proposed for extra compensation—and George Rathbun of New York moved to reduce it from two thousand to 1000 dolls the Committee finally rose without coming to any conclusion and George C. Dromgoole of Virginia announced the decease of his colleague William Taylor with an appropriate Eulogy upon his character and the usual obituary Resolutions—which were passed unanimously by the House Among them was the Resolution to adjourn and the funeral is to take place on Monday next at 1/2 past 12. o’clock. Mr. John Connell spent the evening here and I passed an hour at Mrs. Ogle Tayloe’s weekly evening party. It was small in number but I met there Mr. Healey, Mr. Dubourjal, Mrs. Maury and Mr. and Mrs. Shuyler— This last Lady is a daughter of Dr. Sawyer of Newbury-port with whose Son William Sawyer I was intimately acquainted while I was a student at Law in that Town— With Mrs. Shuyler who at that time was a small child I had now an interesting conversation upon circumstances which occurred at that period and formed a remarkable epoch in my life— It revived recollections of deep interest pleasing and painful— She told me that although too
young at that time to be acquainted with the occurences in which I was so deeply concerned she had heard much about them and mentioned circumstances which came to her knowledge of incidents during my residence in Europe from 1794. to 1801. and of which I had never before heard— She said that she had a Copy of the Vision and I told her of the extraordinary circumstance that a Copy of that Poem was sent to me about three years since when it was published in a New York Newspaper— Whence the copy came I knew not, nor into whose hands it had fallen, though I perfectly knew the hand writing in which it was written and I told her the minute particulars of the engagement to which that Poem gave rise and to its dissolution.

We were somewhat surprised, while at breakfast this morning, by the appearance of Walter Hellen, who arrived last evening, from Zanesville, Ohio. I attended Public Worship, in the Hall of the House Representatives, where Mr. Milburn, the Chaplain of the House preached, from the 2. Corinthians 5.20. “Now then we are embassadors for Christ, as tho God did beseech you by us we pray you in Christ’s stead be ye reconciled to God” Mr. Milburn is a Calvanist and a full believer in the Doctrine of the Atonement, of Regeneration, Election and Predestination yet he enlarged much upon his profession as an Embassador for Christ implying that negotiation at the Throne of God and beseeching of sinners to be reconciled to God may be of some efficasy to the salvation of men— I cannot comprehend the consistency of these Doctrines with each other, for if the Predestination of the Fate of Men be absolute it seems impossible that any negotiation of the Human intellect can be effectual to change it— In the afternoon at Saint Johns Church Mr. Pyne read the evening Service for the second Sunday after the Epiphany and preached from Ephesians 2.8. “For by grace are ye saved through Faith and that not of yourselves it is the gift of God” pure Calvanism again, excluding the idea that any man’s salvation depends upon himself, or can be obtained by any effort of his own to be reconciled to God. A Doctrine still more enforced by the verse immediately following that of the text—“Not of works lest any man should boast” Mr. Pyne however largely commenting upon the . . . is the “gift of God” still admitted that human efforts are not entirely useless for securing that grace which accomplishes salvation by faith. Miss Mary Cutts was here for a few minutes after returning from the Church this afternoon— In my morning reading I have finished the Book of Exodus and commenced the Book of Leviticus. Exodus closes with the description and erection of the Tabernacle of Testimony in the wilderness.

This day was devoted to the funeral services at the interment of William Taylor member of the House of Representatives from the state of Virginia. They were performed according to the usual custom upon the decease of Members of Congress a Committee of Arrangements were appointed by the Speaker consisting of Dromgoold of Virginia Dunlap of Maine McKay of North Carolina Abbott of Mass Hungerford of N.Y. Vantz of Ohio and King of Georgia. Eight Pall Bearers appointed by this Committee were Arnold of Rhode Island Sykes of New Jersey, Ritter of Pennsylvania Chapman of Maryland Black of South Carolina Martin of Tennessee, Houston of Alabama and Boyd of Kentucky attended the corps which was transported into the Hall of the House of Representatives, at 1/2 past 12 o clock. The members of the Senate preceeded by the Vice President and their Secretary came into the House in procession. the Vice President taking his seat at the right hand of the Speaker in his Chair and the Senators being accommodated with seats in the aria fronting Clerks Table. The President of the United States and the members of the Cabinet the Judges of the Supreme Court the Commander in Chief of the Army and other distinguished Officers, Military and Naval occupied seats, in common with the members of the House— A Methodistical Prayer was made by Mr. Milburn the Chaplain of the House of Representatives and a Presbyterian Discourse with some small notice of the Deceased was preached by Mr. Tustan the Chaplain of the Senate after which the Coffin was taken from the Hall and the members of Congress in a procession of Hackney Coaches, went to the Congressional Burying Ground near the Navy Yard where the Body was deposited in the temporary Sepulcher awaiting the usual monument erected over the remains of Members of Congress who die at the seat of Government— I rode in a carriage with Mr. Benjamin Thompson member from the fourth Congressional District of Massachusetts. John F. Scamman member from the first Congressional District of Maine and another member whose name I did not discover— After the deposit of the Body we returned to the Hall of the House of Representatives where the speaker resumed the Chair with about eight or ten members present and immediately adjourned the House till to-morrow. This is the routine of Congressional Funerals it was passed three oclock before I reached home walking from the Capitol—

Mr. Thomas Sandford, was here again this morning an Old Man prosecuting a Claim the origin of which goes back to the last year of the last Century— He has been here once before last week, and now came with sundry Documents in support of his Claim he belongs to Fall river in the state of Massachusetts and in the year 1834 a Petition was presented to the House from him by Tristam Burgess of Rhode-Island referred first to Committee on Commerce and afterwards to the Committee on Ways and Means who reported against it in 1836. Among the Documents which he now produces is a Letter from Commodore Isaac Hull which may possibly have the effect of obtaining a favorable dicision on his Claim— I promised him therefore to call up his old Petition and have it again referred to the Committee of Ways and means—which I accordingly did. At the House which I found in session the Committees were called for Reports and sundry Bills of which notice had previously been given were introduced by individual members after which, on motion of Hannibal Hamlin Chairman of Committee of Elections the House took up with two reports from the majority and minority five to four on the contested election between Edward C. Cabill and William. H. Brockinbro. for the seat of the Representative from Florida Mr. Cabill made some explanation concerning the reports in the newspapers of the former proceedings of the House upon this case Harper of Ohio a minority member of the Committee of Elections, moved a postponement of the case till tomorrow but was resisted by Hamlin, of Maine who insisted upon taking up the case which was carried 95 to 83. A. H. Chapman of Virginia moved and it was resolved that William H Brockinbro who contests he seat of E. C. Cabell have leave to be heard at the Bar of the House The majority and and minority reports of the Committee of Elections were read, with several unsuccessful attempts to suspend the reading. The majority Report concluded with two Resolutions first, that Cabell was not entitled to his seat and that Brokenbro is. the minority report reverses these positions— Hamlin, Chipman, and SJones debated the first majority Resolution till the adjournment of the House at a quarter past three oclock.— There is much excitement by the news yesterday received of the breaking up of the Peal Ministry in England, and the prospect of a new Ministry headed by Lord John Russell—

There was a fall of snow last night and this morning about six inches deep— In the course of the morning the weather cleared up after some rain and a light frost— At the House Howell Cobb of Georgia was appointed on the Committee on Accounts in the place of William Taylor deceased. George W. Jones of Tennessee offered a Resolution calling on the Secretary of the Treasury, for a return of impost Duties received in the year ending 30th. June last with a parrelelstatement of what would have been the proceeds of Duties on the same Articles and all others at an ad valorem rate. Laid over for Debate— Sundry communications from the Navy Department were laid by the Speaker before the House The Florida contested Election was resumed and the Resolutions of the majority Report of the Committee debated chiefly between the members of the Committee till a motion was made by Alexander D. Simms of South Carolina to strike out the Resolution and recommit the case to the Committee to take further evidence relating to the Election I enquired of the Speaker whether the House had not yesterday Resolved that the contestant Brockenbro should be heard in support of his Claim? the Speaker answered that he was. I then suggested that it might be proper to hear the Parties upon the case as it now stood and if that should leave the House unable to decide the Question the motion of Mr. Simms might then be agreed to— Mr. Cabell then moved to suspend the hour rule in favor of Mr. Brockenbro, and Mr. Dobbin moved that it be also suspended in behalf of Mr. Cabell— I objected that the Rule could not apply to Mr. Brockenbro not being admitted as a member of the House nor of course to Mr. Cabell his competitor but was answered that at the last Congress it was decided by the House that the Rule should be applied to both the Parties in the contest between John W. Jones and John M. Botts. The Question was then taken upon the motion to suspend the Rule and lost by yeas and nays 89. to 74. not two thirds. The House then adjourned. There was a Bridal Party in the day time to the house of Mr. F. P. Blair six miles from the City and they went in the evening including my Grandaughter to the Drawing-Room at the Presidents House. I spent the evening at Mr. Markoe’s House by the invitation of Mr Joseph. R. Ingersoll—with a large Party of Gentlemen—

It was close upon midnight last evening when I came home from the Party invited by Mr. Joseph R Ingersoll at the House of Mr. Markoe There had been a luxuriant supper and a numerous assemblage— Mr. James Thompson member of the House from Pennsylvania disappointed by his Hackney Coachman took a seat with me in my Carriage and Fuller took him to his lodgings at Mrs. Hamilton’s in Pennsylvania Avenue— This morning Mr. John Otis of West Barnstable was here proposing still to remain here some weeks in the prosecution of further Claims of the Heirs of his brother William Otis deceased— He inquired if he would stand any chance to obtain employment as a Clerk to any of the Committees of either House of Congress I answered that none of the Committees of the House were allowed to employ Clerks unless by especial note of the House which was very rarely granted. I believed that the Committees of the Senate were more freely indulged. I could give him no encouragement to hope for employment by any of the Committees of the House. He said he was acquainted with none of the Senators except Mr. Webster and with him very slightly— At the House, the resolution offered yesterday by George W. Jones of Tennessee calling on the Secretary of the Treasury for the Amount of Duties imported in the last year to the 30th. June 1845. and the equivalent by an ad valorem duty was adopted without opposition. The Speaker laid before the House a Letter from B. B. French representing his embarassment with regard to the execution of an Order of the House of the 13th. instt. requiring him to distribute among the Members of the present House the copies of Captain Fremont’s Report which an Order of the last House of Representatives had directed should be distributed among it. Members of the 28. Congress— Thereupon James Thompson of Penn moved a Resolution that the Clerk forewith distribute the report of Fremonts expedition acending to the Order of the House of the 13th. January inst a Debate followed whether by the Resolution of the last House there was not vested in the members of the last House a property in the Documents directed to be distributed which it was not competent to the present House to take away and appropriate to themselves— Joseph R. Ingersoll and Schenk of Ohio opposed Thompson’s resolution and Schenck moved as an Amendment to it that five thousand extra Copies of Fremont’s report be printed, for the use of the members of this House and that the Resolution of the 13
instant be rescinded. Cullen Sawtelle of Maine enquired of the Clerk if he had information or knowledge that any member of the last Congress had sold to a Bookseller in Washington Books which he had received in distribution by an Order of the House. Rathburne objected to this Question as not in order The Speaker said he had made enquiry of the Clerk who had answered that he had no such information Sawtelle moved a previous Question Joseph Morris of Ohio moved to lay the subject on the table which was refused The previous Question was carried Schenck Amendment was rejected by yeas and 76 to 106 and Thompsons Resolution was carried also by yeas and nays 94 to 80— Sawtelle then moved a Resolution for the appointment of a Committee of five with power to send for persons and papers to enquire whether any members or members of the 28 Congress had sold Fremonts Report or any other remnent ordered by Congress to be distributed and to Report to the House the name or names of such traders and the facts respecting the sales. The Resolution was extended to the case of members of all other former Congresses and to other Doc and was adopted without opposition. The Florida contested election was then resumed Mr. Cabell the sitting member made two proposals first that the House should take the Question without further Debate and secondly if the contestant should not agree to that they should go back to the People of Florida to settle the contest by a new election both of which Mr. Brockenbrough declined and delivered his own Argument in support of his Claim Mr. Cabell took the floor and the House adjourned by yeas and nays 108 to 64— Mrs. Maury Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal spent part of the evening here—

A person by name Ahasuerus Fundy representing himself as belonging to Watervliet in the State of New York was here this morning— He stated that he had been into Virginia upon some business of his own and had come so far back on his way home and was now destitute of the means of paying the cost of his return. He told a plausible story and prevailed upon me to lend him five dollars to make his way home with a promise of repayment within three weeks— I expect to hear from him no more. At
10. o’clock this morning I attended at the Capitol a Meeting of the Committee on the Smithsonian Bequest. There were present Owen Adams, Jenkins, Marsh, Sims, Davis and Wilmot—all the members. The discussion was renewed upon the Question whether the Directors of the Institution should be constituted in express terms a Corporation for which purpose the Chairman Owen moved a re-consideration of the decision made at the last meeting. it was again debated and again decided to make it a Corporation the vote now being 4. to 3. Owen Chairman changing his vote to the negative and Sims of South Carolina still voting for the Corporation with the avowed intention of voting against the whole Bill and declaring his purpose to have the whole money sent back to the English Court of Chancery— I told him that I thought this proposition came rather late, after the formal acaptance of the bequest and the appropriation of the money to other purposes with a formal pledge of the Faith of the United States that it should be applied to the objects designated by the donor. It was however the original proposition of John C. Calhoun and will be persisted in by the South Carolina School of politics and morals to the last, without any idea of returning the money but with the purpose of defeating any useful application of it— I proposed a provision that all the proceeds of the Bequest be placed in the possession of the Treasurer of the United States with a direction that separate accounts of it should be kept from those of all the other accounts at the Treasury— This had been done in the Act of 1836 which the Committee considered as no longer obligatory since the investment of the Fund almost entirely in Stocks of the States. The provision itself in the Act 1836 was questioned until I produced it and the provision was now at my motion re-inserted in the present Bill. The Committee adjourned to next Friday— In the House Mr. Giddings rose to a Question of privilege. He sent to the Clerk a Report in the National Intelligencer of the speech of Henry Bedinger of Virginia delivered on the 15th. instt. requiring the Clerk to read one paragraph of it grossly insulting him Giddings not by name but with referrence to him equally clear. On commencing his comment he was interrupted by the speaker who observed that leave had not been given him to Address the House on the subject— Vantz moved that he have leave to proceed which was carried without opposition— Giddings said that when Bedinger had made this assault upon him he was not present in the House and had not seen the Report till yesterday when it first
appeared in print. He then referred to a publication in the Savannah Republican the Editor of which he said he understood was a Slave Dealer which article in giving an Account of Bendingers Speech had said that the only way to treat Giddings, was by contempt at the Capitol and holding him up to the scorn of the people thoughout the length and breadth of the Land For that if the House should expel him he would doubtless be returned again by his Constituents. He then added that in the Union newspaper of yesterday a Letter purporting to be written by the New York correspondent of that newspaper urges the same course of conduct and quotes the New York Observer a Religious Paper of that City expressing the same sentiments— Giddings remarked the coincidence between these articles of the newspaper press with the speech of Mr. Bedinger and the fact that yesterday one of the Reporters of the leading Whig paper of this City (Stanbury reporter for National Intelligencer) was hawking about a caricature designed to aid the more elevated calumniaters in their work of detraction— In which caricature he Giddings was made the principal figure. he stated of these facts to the House as indications of a combination to overawe and intimidate the members of this House in the discharge of their duties to their constituents which he thought should be known throughout the length and breadth of the Land. That so far as concerned himself personally the combination came too late he was not sent here for personal altercation with any member of the House nor was it in the power of any such combination to influence or injure him. Bedinger rose and said he was not aware that Giddings was not in his Seat at the time when he made the remarks to which he had referred that he should have used the same words if he had been in his seat that he had as little desire of controversy with him as he on his part could desire that although he might be ambitious it was not of tilting windmills that he regreted the remarks he had made only because they might have helped Giddings in obtaining notoriety— Haralson from Committee on Military Affairs asked leave to make a Report relating to the defences of the Country. Schenck objected unless all the Committees should be called for Reports and moved to postpone the consideration of the Florida election till the Committees should have been called for Reports but the House refused— The Florida Election was resumed and the sitting member Cabell made an hour speech in support of his right
to the seat— Brockenbrough replied by a personal explanation sliding into an Argument.
