Schenck moved that each of the parties should have an other hour—which the House refused Culver and Dobbin members of the Committee of Election, debated the Resolutions Brinkerhoff moved the Previous Question which was not seconded, and the House adjourned on motion of Stevens of Georgia— Stansbury the reporter of Intelligencer and Author of the caricature complained of by Giddings went round the house after the adjournment raving against Giddings who he said had yesterday seen the caricature recognized himself as the principal figure in it with a hearty laugh as Stansbury had supposed of approbation. Mrs Smith continues ill confined to her chamber— Mrs. John Adams and her daughter with Walter Hellen went this evening to a splendid Ball given by Mr. Buchanan the Secretary of State at Carusi Saloon— Mrs. Adams and I spent the evening at home and sent an excuse to Mr. Buchanan that we were studying the title to Oregon— It was an Article by Mr. Furman in a newspaper

Mrs. Beck was here this morning and said she proposed to leave the City, this afternoon, that the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions at a meeting of only four of its members had refused to take up her Petition and returned it to her— Mr. Archibald Atkinson one of its members from Virginia, having observed in her presence that he was not willing to tax his Constituents for such Claims— I requested her to leave the Petition with me and postpone her departure for two or three days during which time I would speak to the Chairman of the Committee and deliver to him the Papers in support of her Claim which she had left but which the Committee had not received perhaps they might change the views of the Committee and induce them to make a favorable Report. At the meeting of the House I spoke accordingly to Mr. Brodhead who told me that Mrs. Beck had misunderstood the proceedings of the Committee in returning her Petition to her which had been in order that she might produce the testimony in support of her claim I delivered the Petition and papers and he assured me that if the testimony would warrant a favourable report I might depend that it would be made. I informed Mrs. Beck of this assurance of the Chairman of the Committee— In the House, the Report of the Committee of Elections on the Florida case was resumed and debated by Stephens of Georgia Seddon of Virginia
and others till the Previous Question was twice moved and the second time succeeded. The two Resolutions reported by the majority of the Committee first that Edward. C. Cabell is not and that William H. Brockenbrough is entitled to the seat as Representative from the State of Florida were successively carried by yeas and nays the first 105 to 80. the second 99. to 85. Jacob Thompson of Mississippi then moved a reconsideration of these votes, and a Resolution to continue the call, till some day in February for further proof But the reconsideration was refused by yeas and nays 86. to 92 and the oath of Office was administered by the Speaker, to Mr. Brockenbrough after which the House adjourned. The decision in this case as in every other case of a contested election except one since I have been a member of the House was glaringly unjust and that was decided by majority of one vote. in this case the decision was by a close Party vote and by majorities, of 15 and less, the usual majority of the dominant party, being from 75 to 80. As I was walking home from the Capital I met Dr. Sutherland who enquired if I had heard the news brought by the Hibernia Steamer arrived at Boston I had not. he said the substance of it was that Lord John Russell had not been able to form an Administration in England and that Sir Robert Peel and his abdicated ministry had been reinstated. This information was confirmed by a Report in the Baltimore Sun newspaper which we received this evening—

In the Hall of the House of Representatives Mr. Tustan the Chaplain of the Senate, was in attendance, gave out the Hymn, which was sung in the old fashion, of reading over two lines at a time, and made the prayer. The preacher, was a Mr. Sillian Bonhomme, a Converted French Israelite, and his discourse, was from Luke, 21.24. “And they shall fall by the edge of the sword and shall be led away captive into all nations and Jerusalem shall be trodden down of the Gentiles until the times of the Gentiles be fulfilled”— The subject was the dispersion and future restoration of the Jews Immediately after announcing the text he turned back, to the 28. & 29. 30. Chapters of Deuteronomy containing the narrative of the blessings and curses promised and denounced by Jehovah as the future
destiny of the children of Israel according as they should prove faithful to their covenant or disobedient to the commandments of their God. He then remarked upon the fulfilment of those prophecies upon the prosperity which they had enjoyed, so long as they had been true to their obligations and to the will of their Maker and upon the two captivities which they had endured in consequence, of their corruption and rebellion against God. The first of these captivities, he said, that of Judah was temporarary having last seventy years after which he had been restored to the Country by Sirus conformably to a prophecy of Isaiah, predicting Sirus by name two hundred years before he was born By the second captivity the ten tribes of Israel had been dispersed among all nations of the earth, and that dispersion had continued until the present day there being now fifteen millions of Jews scattered through the four quarters of the Globe— He then proceeded to indicate the circumstances which portended the final restoration of the Jews according to the Prophecies yet unfulfilled but written in the 28 29. and 30. Chapters of the Book of Dueteronomy.— This he contended was to be accomplished by the final conversion of all the Jews to the Christian Faith of which he was himself one of the pledges That he had been born and bred an Israelite that in the course of his own education, and by his own investigations historical, moral and religious he had become convinced of the truth of Christianity and of the Divine Mission of Jesus as recorded in the New Testament That he had for many years preached Christ crucified, to his own kindred the Jews in various parts of the world and with encouraging success— He gave numerous instances of Jews who had been converted to the Faith of Christ by his labors and who had received the rite of Baptism. He concluded by saying that as it was not usual to take up a collection in that Hall, he would give notice that if any person was disposed to make a small contribution to promote the success of this work he might deposit his gift in the hands of any of the Clergymen of this City— In the afternoon at St John’s Church a Stranger, read prayers for the third Sunday after Epiphany, and preached from Matthew 12.18. “Behold my servant, whom I have chosen My beloved, in whom my Soul is well pleased. I will put my Spirit upon him and he shall show judgment to the Gentiles. 19. He shall not strive nor cry, neither shall any man hear his voice in the streets 20. A bruised reed shall he not break and smoking flax shall he not quench till he send forth judgment unto victory. 21. And in his name
shall the Gentiles trust”— The preacher observed that this was a quotation, from a prophecy in the Book of Isaiah. 42 Chapter 1. and following verses—and he alledged the reasons for concluding that that passage from the Prophet could apply to no other person than to Jesus Christ. The Apostle Matthew expressly declares it to be the fulfilment of that Prophecy but some of the Modern Biblical commentators have made it a Question— Gov Seward and Mr. Robinson the Reporter and Mr. Charles B. King the Painter were here this evening— Gov Seward has been passing some days at Richmond Virginia. He spoke of some proceedings in the Legislature of New York and counter proceedings of certain Whigs of the City New York respecting the Oregon Question portending some dissension of opinions the result of which he seemed to think was doubtful—but he said that the recent news of Ministerial revolutions in England had revived the belligerent spirit of the Administration Party here—

I received this morning a Letter from Mr. Lewis Cruger of New York stating that he had received no answer to his with which he had sent me a printed pamphlet copy of the Journal of the First Congress held at Albany in 1765. I had answered his letter on the 11th. December last and know not how it has happened that he did not receive it— After making a deposit at the Bank of the Metropolis and drawing a Check upon it I went to the House which I found in Session, I had expected that the day would be devoted to the reception of Petitions, but I found that Thomas Butler King of Georgia had presented for consideration two joint Resolutions respecting the Oregon Territory which were read—and ordered to be printed together with the Resolution for giving notice reported by the Committee Foreign Affairs and the several amendments already proposed to it. Preston King of New York moved a Resolution proposing a Debate on the Resolution at 2 P.M next Monday, Charles. J. Ingersoll inquired if he had consulted with any member of the Committee of Foreign Affairs before proposing this Resolution. King answered that they all knew of it now. King said he did not ask the House to take it up now but to lay it on Table for future consideration it was laid on Table
John Wentworth gave notice of an Amendment which he proposed to move when it should be taken up. Preston King then moved to suspend the Rules to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the Notice Question, which was carried by yeas and nays 112. to 52— The Whigs, voting for it to give John S. Pendleton of Virginia chance to make a speech against the Notice— Tibbatts took the Chair and Pendleton made his speech upon the whole the strongest that has been made during the present Session of Congress— It was one like one once made in the British Parliament which was said to have broken out like the Irish rebellion thirty-thousand strong— He was followed by Cullen Sawtelle of Maine and Martin Grover of New York in support of the Notice— Stephen A. Douglass of Quincy Illinois then took the floor and moved the Committee to rise— McKay Chairman of the Committee Ways and Means moved to lay aside the Oregon Resolutions and take up the Fortification Appropriation Bill— A sly movement—no quorum meet on it. The Committee rose and reported no quorum— Brodhead moved a Call of the House which was refused— Motion was made to adjourn and withdrawn upon a call of yeas and nays— Another motion for call of the House—refused— Joseph R. Ingersoll moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up Fortification Bill, refused— Another motion to adjourn rejected by yeas and nays 50. to 79— The Speaker laid sundry Documents before the House. Brodhead moved to go into Committee of the whole on state of Union— Hudson moved to adjourn which without yeas and nays was carried and the House adjourned. Evening visit from Mr. William Miller

Mrs. Beck was here this morning and took leave being about to return home— She said she had seen Mr Brodhead who told her he would consult with me respecting a report in her favour.— I thought it would be of no use use for her to remain longer here but she had not the means of returning without assistance— At the House— George W. B. Towns took his seat as a Member from Georgia. Erastus D. Culver of New York presented a Memorial from certain Citizens of New Hampshire praying that the right of the Members from that State—Morris Norris Jr.
James. H. Johnson and Mace Moulton to their Seats should be inquired into and the Seats vacated as they had been elected by a general Ticket in express violation of an Act of Congress which was referred to Committee on Elections. The Speaker called the Committees for Reports many of which, Public and Private were made— Charles J. Ingersoll from the Committee Foreign Affairs made a Report asking to be discharged from a Memorial of Citizens of Easton Pennsylvania, complaining of the conduct of the Commander of a British man of war, towards the Colony at Liberia, and that this Colony should be recognised as an Independent Government by the U.S. report was laid on Table and ordered to be printed. The call of reports from Committees was not completed when the House on motion of Hopkins of Virginia went into Committee of the whole on the State of Union Tibbatts in the Chair on the Oregon Notice Question— Stephen A. Douglass of Illinois Chairman of the Committee on Territories made an hour speech . . .ing the Notice insisting upon the whole of Oregon and . . .ing against any compromise by the sacrifice of the . . .. Thomas. H. Bayly of Acomac Court House Virginia doled out rivulets of a speech which he proposes to publish against giving the notice a Slave monger Speech— W. W. Ca. . . a native American from the City of New York occupied an hour on the Notice intermixed with nativism— Robert Dale Owen of Indiana moved the Committee to rise and the same immediately after adjourned— Mrs. John Adams and her daughter Mary Louisa, with Walter Hellen went to a Ball given by Dr. and Mrs. Heiskell, who reside with Mr. and Mrs. Gouverneur Mrs. Heiskell’s parents— We read this evening one of the Articles in the National Intelligencer by Albert Gallatin, the third of a series of four Letters which he is publishing on that subject.

Mr. John Gray was here and I returned to him his two manuscript Treatises upon the relative powers of the Legislature and the Judiciary by the Constitution of the United States. He renewed indirectly a proposition

which he had made heretofore of a contingent Fee of five thousand dollars to me to argue the Question before the Supreme Court of the U. States which I had already and did now again decline— I am to wait for the Bill from the Senate in the Claim of the Representatives of James Bell— Had a visit from Mr. John P. Kennedy with a Friend of his from Baltimore— I dispatched Letters, to my Son, to Mr. Lewis Cruger of New York, and to Jesse Perkins of North Bridgewater with a notification which I received this morning from W. J. Brown Second Assistant Postmaster General, that two applications had been received for the appointment of Postmaster at North Bridgewater in place of Edward Southworth the present incumbent— When I entered the the House the Question was taking on a Motion by Charles J. Ingersoll from the Committee Foreign Affairs to close the Debate on the Oregon Notice Resolution on Thursday at 2 o’clock p.m. 5. Feb. After refusing a call for yeas and nays, and a vote which the Speaker decided was against the motion. Houston moved to lay it on the Table which was carried— Went into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union Tibbatts in the Chair Robert Dale Owen of Indiana then made an hour speech in support of the notice—followed by Allen G. Thurman, of Ohio, whose argument was chiefly confined to a refutation of the minority Report from the Committee of Foreign Affairs which was based on the position that the giving of the Notice was the prerogative of the Executive with which Congress had nothing to do—he insisted that this was an erroneous principle as I had done at the last Session of Congress when it was first asserted by the then Chairman of the Committees on Territories— Then came an hour Speech from James Thompson of Pennsylvania whom I had met a few days since at Mr. Markoe’s. He was in favor of giving the notice and made the most humorous Speech of the Session— Isaac E. Holmes of Charleston South Carolina moved the Committee to rise and the House adjourned after Alexander H. Stephens had presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Georgia against any alteration, in the Constitution of the United States of the bases of Representation These are counter Resolutions to those of the Legislature of Mass proposing an Amendment to abolish the Slave Representation— Evening visits from Mr. Rockwell
of Connecticut with his friend, Mr. Catlin and from Mr. George Sykes of New Jersey with five Citizens of that State whose names escaped me

Before I reached the House this morning Emile Lasere appeared and took his seat as a member of the House from the state of John Slidell resigned. He having received an appointment as Envoy extraordinary and minister Plenipotentiary to Mexico. Charles J. Ingersoll introduced again a Resolution for closing the Debate in the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union on the Oregon Notice Resolution on Saturday the 7. next month at 2. p.m. two days later than in the Resolution which he offered yesterday— Tibbatts moved to lay the Resolution on the Table Brinkerhoff called for yeas and nays which were 84. to 52.— I entered the House while the yeas and nays were taking on this Question and of course had not the opportunity to vote upon it The House went immediately into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Tibbatts in the Chair and Isaac E. Holmes of South Carolina made an hour Speech of fervid eloquence against the giving of the notice, painting all the horrors real and imaginary of a War with Great Britain excepting that which at the Bottom of his heart swallowed up all others the terror of emancipation of Slaves which he foresaw as among the most probable consequences of such a war—next to him Edward H. Ewing of Nashville Tennessee argued also against the giving of the notice and for the first time undertook to show that the American title to Oregon was very far from being clear and indisputable—he too had a proper horror for the calamities of war though a Representative of the State from which the President of the United States comes— Edward D. Baker of Springfield Illinois, succeeded warmly in support of the notice— Joseph P. Hoge of Galena in the same State of Illinois moved the Committee to rise which was carried and the House adjourned— As this Debate proceeds it is apparent that the President and his Administration Party are faltering in the spirit which they so boldly assumed in the Baltimore Convention which nominated Mr. Polk for the Presidency and in his corresponding declaration of his Inaugural Address—

Further evidence appears of the flinching of the Polk Administration upon the Oregon Controversy with Great Britain— In the Union newspaper of last Tuesday—there was an Article, strongly intimating, that if a proposition should be made on the part of Great Britain to take theof the 49. degree of Latitude as the Boundary to the Pacific Ocean, describing it as the offer made by me it might now be accepted. In the Debate in the Senate on Wednesday this Article was referred to, by Mr. Miller a Senator from New Jersey as very clearly indicating that Mr. Polk has no fear of war to arise from this Question Edward. A. Hannagan Senator from Indiana rose and averred upon his responsibility that this Article had never been seen by President Polk before its publication and was not approved by him— The Union of this day admits the fact, but repeats the opinion expressed in the original Article— At ten o’clock this morning I attended a meeting of the Select Commitee on the Smithsonian Bequest present six Members—Owen, Adams, Jenkins, Sims—Davis, Wilmot—absent Marsh of Vermont who afterwards told me that it was because he had forgotten the time of the Meeting—Some progress very little was made in the discussion of Mr. Owen’s Bill, in the Sixth Section provision is made for a superintendant to take charge of the ground, Buildings and property belonging to the Institution—and also for the Appointment of a Professor of Agriculture, Horticulture and Rural economy and also for a distribution among the people of the Union of Fruits, Plants, Seeds and Vegetables to be collected by this Superintendent with the Professor, and Gardiners, practical Agriculturists, and Labourers to be hired from time to time by him, as may be necessary— I moved to strike out this Section, which consider as a cumbersome expensive, and useless burden upon the Institution— It was connected also with a further project, declared in the seventh Section, for the appointment of a Normal Branch of the Institution, with an indefinite number of professors of common School and other scientific Instruction—all which I proposed to expunge from the Bill— The discussion was desultory, and before taking the Question upon it some Amendments of detail to the Sixth Section were proposed and debated until the meeting of the House when the Committee adjourned to next Friday. At the House the Committees were called for Reports—many of which were made, but none of any material importance. Stephens of Georgia presented
resolutions from that state claiming re-imbursements for sundry expenses incurred by that State in the late Wars with the Indians, commonly called the Florida War. Committee of the Whole on State of the Union—Tibbatts in the Chair. Joseph P. Hoge of Galena Illinois and William Wick of Indianapolis Illinois in two successive hour Speeches supported the giving of the Notice and took to task the latter with merciless sarcasm, the contrast of bullying and of sneaking off the South Carolina politicians with John C. Calhoun at their head. He ridiculed their clamours about war, though he admitted, that War might terminate in the result of this Controversy and Andrew Johnson of Tennessee took the floor but the Bill was laid aside and a Bill from the Senate to establish certain post roads in the State of Texas was taken up— Erastus. D. Culver of Greenwich New York, made an hour Speech against the Bill on the grounds of unconstitutionality insisting that the Annexation of Texas to this Union by mere Act of Congress was UnConstitutional null and void and would be so decided he had no doubt by the Supreme Court of the United States if the Question could be brought before them. He reviewed with severe censure all the proceedings of the Democratic Party and of the Administration in the rise, progress and consummation of that iniquitous measure— He adverted to the deception practised upon the People of the North at the Baltimore Convention by the substitution of James K Polk for Martin Van Buren as the candidate of the Party for the Presidency of the United States, and in the adoption of two Resolutions one for the Annexation of Texas and the other declaring the right of the United States to the whole of Oregon to 54.40— as clear and unquestionable and now after completing the Annexation of Texas falling back and manifesting the design to abandon if not the whole a large portion of Oregon even to the mouth of Columbia river with the free navigation of it— Culver was several times called to order by southern members—and especially in a very insulting manner by McConnell of Alabama but the Chairman steadily and resolutely declared him in order to the great annoyance of the interrupting members who dared not however take an appeal from his decisions— Culver finished his Speech without losing his temper and McConnell sputtered a few sentences in reply to him of personal insult of which he took no notice— The Committee of the Whole then reported the Bill and with the help of the Previous Question it was passed
without Amendment and without further opposition. Walter Hellen went to an evening Party at the House of Gov. Marcy the Secretary of War, and we were amused by the reading of a review of the Life of Capt Kidd in a number of Littell’s Living Age

I found the House this morning in Debate upon a Resolution moved to print 5500. extra copies of a Report from Secretary of War transmitting an abstract of the Pension Laws and the construction of them given by the Department of War and the Attorney General—which had been laid before the House by the Speaker— The resolution was finally adopted and the result of the Debate was to print 10,500. extra copies of the Document, sundry other executive Documents from the Department were presented by the Speaker. Committee of the whole on the State of the Union on a Bill relating to Custom House Officers which was debated reported to the House, and passed. The House subsequently went into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union again Tibbatts in the Chair and took up the Oregon Notice Resolution Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, made an hour speech for earnest in support of giving the notice, in which much to my surprise, he completely refuted a charge against me, made by Thomas H. Bayly fromVirginia, who by reading garbled extracts from my speech made on the 31st. January last year, had misrepresented my opinions then expressed as being inconsistent with my Speech on the same subject at the present Session. Bayly who is a Beef-witted blunderhead had borrowed this charge, from some of the Party newspapers, without discovering the false colouring wilfully and intentionally given, by the Articles in the newspapers to my Speeches at the two different periods. The inconsistency imputed to me, was by picking out from my last winters speech the opposition that I had then made to the Bill for organizing the Oregon Territory reported without a section for giving notice to Great Britain of the termination of the non occupation Convention. I had said that this would be equivalent to war which if thus incurred I had foretold would prove not only disastrous but unjust and unpopular— This morning before the House went into Committee on this subject Johnson came to me and referring to the attack upon me made by Bayly said he had understood my speech in a total different sense and that my objections had been made entirely
provision for giving the Previous Notice of twelve months required by the Convention and he observed that I had actually proposed as an Amendment to the Bill, a first section directing the notice to be given which the House had rejected though afterwards they had adopted a similar Section at the close of the Bill moved by Hamet? of Mississippi and that I had then said that after long deliberation and with great reluctance I had come to the conclusion that the time was come for giving the notice and was ready to vote for it—either by a separate resolution or as a first section to the Territorial— I told Johnson that he perfectly understood my speech as I had then delivered it and that it had been totally misrepresented by Mr. Bayly. I did not then know nor expect that Johnson meant to expose the misrepresentation of Mr. Bayly, but he did so in his speech, thoroughly and unsparingly. I had intended, to perform that service myself which I shall perhaps now forbear to do. Mr. Wood followed—with a -faced speech declaring he should vote for the Notice but arguing very strenuously against it— Jacob Thompson took the floor moved the Committee to rise and the House adjourned— I dined with Mr. Seward of N.Y. at Coleman’s National Hotel with a small Party consisting of Hugh White and two or three other members from State of N.Y. Mr. C. L. Livingston and one or two others— Gov Seward came home with me and passed half an hour in the evening with us. The weather has been for two or three days almost too warm for spring—
